params.text:
• Understand the use of instructions
  • Identify key expressions and grammar
  • Better understand obligations

Reading

Understand Simple Instructions 1

Language in Action
Reading: Introduction

This module equips you with the skills to conquer simple instructions you might encounter in everyday life. 

Here's what you'll explore:

1. The Power of Instructions: Learn why instructions are important and how they help us complete tasks successfully.

  2. Key Expressions & Grammar: Discover common phrases and grammatical structures used in giving instructions.

  3. Understanding Obligations: Become an expert at identifying what "must do," "should do," and "can do" mean in instructions.
Understand the use of instructions: Key Points

Instructions are everywhere in the business world, guiding us through tasks and ensuring everyone's on the same page.

Here are some tips:
• Why are Instructions Important?
• Spotting Instructions:

Instructions come in many forms in the business world, not just lengthy manuals! Look for them in:

  • Emails: Emails might contain instructions for completing a specific task, like preparing for a meeting or submitting a sales report.
  • Memos: Memos from managers often outline new procedures or company policies, which essentially act as instructions.
  • Software Programs: Many programs have built-in instructions or tutorials to guide users through the steps.

Imagine a new employee starting their first day! Without clear instructions, they might not know how to use the company printer or submit an expense report. Instructions help us:

  • Do things correctly: Following instructions ensures tasks are completed accurately and efficiently.
  • Maintain quality: Clear instructions lead to consistent results, which is important in business.
  • Save time: By understanding what to do, you can avoid confusion and wasted time.
Understand the use of instructions: Opinions
Micah:
Bryan:
Anthony:

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: It's your first day, and you're feeling a little lost. You see a colleague struggling with the photocopier and can't remember how to use it yourself. What would be MOST helpful in this situation?
answers:
Look for any instructions or labels near the copier that might explain how to use it.

Take a long break and wait for someone to show you how to use the copier later.

Ask your colleague a question, even though they seem busy themselves.

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: Your manager has sent a company-wide email with clear instructions on how to submit travel expense reports. Why might these instructions be important?
answers:
To ensure everyone submits their reports in the same way and avoid errors

So you can learn interesting facts about different travel destinations. 

To see how many times your colleagues have traveled for work this year.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: You're working on a new software program for managing customer data. The program has a built-in help menu with step-by-step instructions for using different features. What benefit might these instructions offer?
answers:
They can show you how to use the program's features quickly and easily.

They will entertain you with funny jokes and stories.

They will tell you all about the company's history and values.

metadata.title: Understand the use of instructions Quiz

params.text: What Would You Do? Quiz
Imagine you're a new employee at a company. Use your detective skills to figure out the importance of instructions in these situations!
Identify Key Expressions And Grammar: Key Points

Instructions might seem like a jumble of words, but don't worry!
Here are some detective tricks to help you identify key expressions and grammar that will crack the instruction code:
• Instruction Verbs - Action Heroes!
• Sequencing & Order Words - Keeping Track!

• Instructions often involve steps in a specific order. Look for words that show sequence, like "first," "then," "next," "after that," or "finally." These help you understand the order in which to complete the tasks.
    Example: "First, power on the computer. Then, log in using your username and password. Finally, open your email." (Identify sequencing words like "First" and "Then")

• Instructions are all about action! Look for verbs that tell you exactly what to do. These are your action heroes, like "open," "click," "submit," or "fill in."
    Example: "To print a document, open the file and click on 'Print'." (Focus on verbs like "open" and "click")
• Nouns & Adjectives - Knowing the Players!

• Instructions involve people, objects, and their descriptions. Look for nouns (people or things) and adjectives (describing words) to understand what you're working with and how it should be.
    Example: Select the desired document (noun) and click on "Print" (verb). Choose the correct paper size (adjective + noun) from the options.
• Imperative Mood - Be Direct!

• Instructions like giving orders! They often use the imperative mood, which is a verb form that tells someone to do something directly. Look for verbs without a subject ("open," "click"), or ending in "-s" ("prints," "saves").
    Example: "Turn on the printer. Insert the paper. Press the 'Print' button." (Verbs in the imperative mood like "Turn on" and "Insert")
Identify Key Expressions And Grammar - Sentences

questions:
Hi Team,

This is a *friendly* reminder to please *submit* the minutes from our meeting last Friday by tomorrow at 5pm. The minutes help us remember what was discussed and any *decisions* we made. To submit your minutes, you can simply *reply* to this email and copy and paste your notes from the meeting.

If you have any *questions* about what to include in the minutes, please don't *hesitate* to ask!

Thanks, Frank

metadata.title: Identify Key Expressions And Grammar - Fill in the Blanks

params.text: Identify Key Expressions And Grammar - Forum & Quiz
You are on an online forum where people are discussing  how they identify key expressions in emails. Please read the posts and answer the questions below:

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: Abigail says instructions use words to show order. What phrase helps with this?
answers:
Words like "first," "then," and "finally"

Adjectives describing size or color

Verbs like "click" or "submit"

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: Bryan says verbs are important in instructions. Why are verbs helpful?
answers:
They tell you exactly what to do, like "open" or "print."

They describe the appearance of objects in the instructions.

They tell you interesting facts about the task you're completing.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: Micah says instructions use words to describe things. What kind of word might be used for this purpose?
answers:
Adjectives like "big" or "small"

Verbs that tell you actions to take 

Sequencing words like "next" or "finally"

params.text: Abigail:
Bryan:

Abigail: "I always look for words that tell me the order I need to do things. Words like 'first,' 'then,' and 'finally' help me follow the steps one by one. It's like a mini recipe for completing the task!"

Bryan: "Verbs are super important in instructions! They tell you exactly what to do, like 'click,' 'open,' or 'submit.' If I see an instruction with lots of action verbs, I know I can understand it because they tell me what to do step-by-step."

Micah: "Don't forget about the words that describe things! Instructions might use adjectives to tell you what kind of file to open or what size paper to choose. These details help you complete the task accurately."
Micah:
Identify Key Expressions And Grammar: Key Points

Instructions often use words that tell you what's obligatory (required), recommended (good idea), or optional (up to you).

Here are some detective skills to help you decipher these obligations:
• Spotting the Clues:
• Context is King!
• The surrounding words and phrases can also provide clues. For example, "It is important to..." often suggests something is important but not necessarily mandatory.

Look for specific verbs that indicate the level of obligation. Here are some common ones:

  • Must: This means something is absolutely necessary and you have to do it. (e.g., "You must submit the report by Friday.") "submit," or "fill in."
  • Should: This suggests something is recommended or a good idea, but not strictly mandatory. (e.g., "You should save your work regularly.")
  • Can: This indicates something is optional and up to your own decision. (e.g., "You can contact me if you have any questions.")
• Understanding the Purpose:
• Consider the purpose of the instructions. If they are about safety procedures, then following them precisely ("must") is crucial. For less critical tasks, there might be more flexibility ("can").

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: Bryan is confused about the difference between "must" and "should" in the instructions. What does Abigail say "must" means?
answers:
It means something is absolutely necessary, like a rule.

It's a suggestion about using the software program more often.

It's a good idea but not mandatory to follow a certain step.

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: Abigail gives the example "You must save your work before closing the program." What does this tell you about saving your work?
answers:
It's important to save your work before closing the program. 

It's a suggestion that you might want to save your work.

You can choose to save your work whenever you want.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: According to the conversation, what does "can" typically indicate in instructions?
answers:
It suggests something is optional and up to your decision.

It's something you must do to use the software program correctly.

It means "can" is not relevant to using the software program.

params.text: Better Understand Obligations - Conversation and Quiz
Please listen to the conversation between Bryan and Abigail, and answer the questions below:
Dialogue Text:

Bryan: I'm working on these new instructions for the software program, but I'm a little confused.

Abigail: Oh no! What part is tricky?

Bryan: Well, it uses a lot of words like "must" and "should." I'm not sure what the difference is.

Abigail: Ah, that makes sense. "Must" means something is absolutely necessary, like "You must save your work before closing the program."

Bryan: Okay, so "must" is like a rule I have to follow?

Abigail: Exactly! "Should" is a suggestion, like "You should back up your files regularly to avoid losing data." It's a good idea, but not mandatory.

Bryan: I see! So, "can" is probably optional then?

Abigail: Yes, "can" means it's up to you. For example, "You can contact us if you need further assistance."
Bryan:

params.text: Abigail:
Module Summary Quiz
Test your instruction-following skills! Choose the BEST answer for each question to show what you learned in this module.

choices.question: Question 1 of 6: You're reading an email with instructions for submitting a travel expense report. What is the MOST IMPORTANT reason for these instructions?
answers:
To ensure everyone submits their reports in the same way and avoids errors.

To share interesting facts about different travel destinations.

To entertain you with a funny story about expense reports.

choices.question: Question 2 of 6: When following instructions, it's helpful to ask yourself questions like "Who, What, When, Why." Why is this a good strategy?
answers:
It helps you identify the key verbs that tell you what to do.

It allows you to skip irrelevant details about the instructions. 

It helps you gather clues about the purpose and content of the instructions.

choices.question: Question 3 of 6: You see the phrase "Click on 'Print'" in a set of instructions. What part of speech is "Click" and how does it help you understand the instruction?
answers:
It's a verb that tells you exactly what action to take. 

It's a noun describing the printer you need to use. 

It's an adjective describing the type of document to print.

choices.question: Question 4 of 6: An email from your manager asks you to "Please submit the report by tomorrow." What level of obligation does this suggest?
answers:
It's a good idea to submit the report by tomorrow, but it's not mandatory.

You can choose to submit the report whenever you have time.

Submitting the report is absolutely necessary and you must do it by tomorrow.

choices.question: Question 5 of 6: You're looking for instructions on how to use the company's new photocopier. Where might you find them?
answers:
By asking a colleague, even though they seem busy.

In a company-wide meeting where new procedures are discussed. 

On a label or booklet located near the photocopier itself.

choices.question: Question 6 of 6: Why might instructions for a new software program include step-by-step instructions and tutorial videos?
answers:
To help you learn the program quickly and easily by following clear steps.

To test your knowledge of using computers in general. 

To show off the company's graphic design skills in the video tutorials.
